node.data: Project Gutenberg is a digital library and online platform that offers free access to a large collection of electronic works, most of which are in the public domain in the United States. This initiative is focused on the free distribution of electronic works in formats readable by a wide variety of computers. It relies on volunteers and donations to maintain its collection and mission. Among its offerings are notable works such as "A Christmas Carol," which are distributed without copyright restrictions in the United States.
Charles Dickens is the author of "A Christmas Carol"
Arthur Rackham is the illustrator of "A Christmas Carol"
J. B. Lippincott Company is the original publisher of "A Christmas Carol" in Philadelphia and New York

The United States is the country where the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation operates and complies with charity laws. It is also the country where Project Gutenberg is based and where eBooks are freely available. Project Gutenberg operates and distributes electronic works without copyright restrictions in the United States, where most of its works are in the public domain and where the relevant copyright laws apply. Additionally, the United States is mentioned in the context of a security that would become irrelevant if there were no days to count by.
"A Christmas Carol" is a novella by Charles Dickens, first published in 1843, that tells the story of Ebenezer Scrooge's transformation after being visited by ghosts.
Suzanne Shell is one of the producers of the Project Gutenberg eBook of "A Christmas Carol"
Janet Blenkinship is one of the producers of the Project Gutenberg eBook of "A Christmas Carol"
The Online Distributed Proofreading Team is a group that helped produce the Project Gutenberg eBook of "A Christmas Carol"
Philadelphia is one of the cities where "A Christmas Carol" was originally published
New York is one of the cities where "A Christmas Carol" was originally published

Bob Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol" by Charles Dickens. He is the clerk and employee of Ebenezer Scrooge, working diligently to support his family despite earning only fifteen 'Bob' a week. Bob lives in a modest four-roomed house and is known for his threadbare clothes and long comforter. He is a caring father to his children, including his son Tiny Tim, and a devoted husband to Mrs. Cratchit. Bob is depicted as a hardworking and humble man who, despite his financial struggles, maintains a positive and loving demeanor towards his family. On Christmas Eve, he asks Scrooge for a day off and enjoys sliding on Cornhill. Although he is sometimes late to work, Scrooge eventually promises him a raise and assistance for his struggling family. Bob Cratchit is also noted for his kindness, as he takes Tiny Tim beside him at the table and proposes a toast. In a gesture of newfound generosity, Scrooge plans to send a large turkey to the Cratchit family as a surprise gift.

Ebenezer Scrooge is the main character in "A Christmas Carol," known for being a grasping, covetous old man. He is confronted by a ghost and is deeply troubled by the encounter. Scrooge wakes up in a dark room and experiences strange events, which lead him to read his own name on a neglected grave.
Peter Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol" and one of Bob Cratchit's children. He is depicted as a son of Bob Cratchit who is considering a job opportunity.
Tim Cratchit, also known as Tiny Tim, is a character in "A Christmas Carol," the youngest son of Bob Cratchit and a cripple
Mr. Fezziwig is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a kind-hearted, jovial old merchant.

Fred is a character in "A Christmas Carol," the nephew of Ebenezer Scrooge. He is known for his warm and welcoming nature, particularly towards his uncle. Fred invited Scrooge to dinner and hosted the game during the gathering. He also led the toast to Scrooge, demonstrating his kind-hearted and inclusive spirit.

The Ghost of Christmas Past is a character in "A Christmas Carol." This supernatural entity is a spirit that visits Scrooge to show him scenes from his past. By illuminating Scrooge's memories and interactions, the Ghost of Christmas Past helps him reflect on his earlier life experiences.

The Ghost of Christmas Present is a character in "A Christmas Carol," known for his kind, generous, and hearty nature. He is depicted as a jolly giant who appears to Scrooge, dressed in a green robe bordered with white fur, and surrounded by festive decorations and food. This spirit is a specific manifestation that visits Scrooge to show him scenes from the present, highlighting the joy and festivities of Christmas. The Ghost of Christmas Present also blesses Bob Cratchit's house with the sprinklings of his torch, spreading joy and blessings. As a supernatural entity, he plays a crucial role in revealing the current state of Scrooge's life and the lives of others, emphasizing the importance of generosity and the Christmas spirit.

node.id: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS YET TO COME
node.data: The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come is a character in "A Christmas Carol." This solemn Phantom is one of the spirits that visits Scrooge, showing him visions of the future. The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come reveals the shadows of things which yet may happen, illustrating the potential future consequences of Scrooge's actions.
The Ghost of Jacob Marley is a character in "A Christmas Carol." He is the spectral form of Scrooge's former business partner who appears to warn Scrooge of the impending visits by three spirits.

Joe is a character in "A Christmas Carol," depicted as an old man who operates as a marine-store dealer and receiver of stolen goods. He is known for appraising and buying items from others. Additionally, Joe is involved in a scene where he discusses bed-curtains with a woman, further illustrating his role in the story.
Mr. Topper is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a bachelor
Dick Wilkins is a character in "A Christmas Carol." He is a fellow apprentice of Ebenezer Scrooge and was very much attached to him.
Belle is a character in "A Christmas Carol," known as a comely matron and an old sweetheart of Scrooge's. She is also the wife of the master of the house and an old acquaintance of Scrooge.

Caroline is a character in "A Christmas Carol." She is the wife of one of Scrooge's debtors. Caroline experiences a mix of hope and relief upon hearing about the death of a merciless creditor, reflecting her feelings of relief at the passing of someone who had been a harsh and unforgiving presence in her life.

Mrs. Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol," the wife of Bob Cratchit and mother of Tiny Tim. She is described as being dressed poorly in a twice-turned gown but makes a good show with ribbons. Despite her modest attire, she takes pride in her appearance and responsibilities. Mrs. Cratchit is responsible for laying the cloth, preparing the meal, making the gravy, and preparing the pudding for the family dinner. She expresses strong negative feelings towards Scrooge and speaks about her children, Peter and Tiny Tim. As a member of the Cratchit family, she plays a significant role in their household and the story.

Belinda Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol." She is the second daughter of Bob and Mrs. Cratchit. Belinda assists her mother in preparing the meal and is described as being brave in ribbons.

Martha Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol" and the eldest daughter of Bob and Mrs. Cratchit. She works as a poor apprentice at a milliner's, which causes her to arrive late to family gatherings. Despite her tardiness, she is warmly welcomed by her family. In one memorable scene, she hides to surprise her father, Bob Cratchit, showcasing the close and loving bond within the Cratchit family.

Mrs. Dilber is a character in "A Christmas Carol." She is a laundress who brings items to Joe for appraisal and sale. Additionally, she is depicted as a woman who enters Old Joe's shop with a heavy bundle.
Fan is a character in "A Christmas Carol," known as the younger sister of Scrooge. She plays a significant role by coming to bring him home for Christmas.

Mrs. Fezziwig is a character in "A Christmas Carol," known as the worthy partner and wife of Old Fezziwig. She is equally lively and skilled in dancing, often participating in the domestic ball and Christmas Eve festivities. Mrs. Fezziwig is recognized for her substantial smile and her enthusiastic participation in the celebrations, including dancing with Old Fezziwig.

node.id: THE FIRST OF THE THREE SPIRITS
node.data: The First of the Three Spirits is the initial supernatural entity that will visit Scrooge. This entity is featured in the second chapter of "A Christmas Carol," where Scrooge is visited by the Ghost of Christmas Past.

node.id: THE SECOND OF THE THREE SPIRITS
node.data: The Second of the Three Spirits is the third chapter of "A Christmas Carol," where Scrooge is visited by the Ghost of Christmas Present
The Last of the Spirits is the fourth chapter of "A Christmas Carol," where Scrooge is visited by the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come
The End of It is the fifth and final chapter of "A Christmas Carol," where Scrooge's transformation is complete

Marley's Ghost is a supernatural entity that haunts Scrooge and warns him of future visitations. It is the apparition of Jacob Marley, who appears to Scrooge to forewarn him about his fate and the impending visits of three spirits. This ghostly encounter causes Scrooge great fear and disbelief.

FEZZIWIG is an old gentleman who was Scrooge's employer during his apprenticeship. He is a character known for his jovial and benevolent nature, running a business with a lively and generous spirit. Fezziwig is particularly noted for his enthusiasm during Christmas Eve celebrations, where he hosts a domestic ball, spreading cheer among his guests. He is also described as a skilled dancer, often standing out to dance with Mrs. Fezziwig, further highlighting his lively and festive personality.

Scrooge is a central character in the narrative who undergoes a profound transformation. Initially, he is depicted as a miserly, solitary old man, known for his tight-fisted, squeezing, wrenching, grasping, scraping, clutching, and covetous nature. He is cynical about Christmas, disdainful towards his clerk, and uncharitable, particularly during the Christmas season. Scrooge is also described as cold and unfeeling, both physically and emotionally, and is the subject of much discussion and disdain among the Cratchit family.
Scrooge's journey begins with his skepticism and disbelief in supernatural occurrences, particularly when confronted by the ghost of his former business partner, Marley. He is then visited by various spirits, including the Ghost of Christmas Past, the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, and other phantoms, who guide him through scenes of Christmas celebrations and reflections on his life. These supernatural events and reflections evoke a range of emotions in Scrooge, from joy to sorrow, agitation, and anxiety.
Throughout these encounters, Scrooge is shown scenes from his past, including interactions with his sister and schoolmaster, and is made to reflect on his actions and their consequences. He observes a dark room and a dead man, feeling anxious and powerless in the presence of a Phantom, and is horrified by the actions of Joe and others. Scrooge also shows concern for Tiny Tim's future and speaks with the Ghost about it.
A significant turning point occurs when Scrooge participates in games and is the subject of a guessing game, which leads him to question his actions and intentions. He is surprised by the laughter of his nephew and is described as a comical old fellow who, despite his unpleasant demeanor, is very rich.
Ultimately, Scrooge undergoes a remarkable transformation. He becomes generous and kind-hearted, especially towards Bob Cratchit and Tiny Tim. By the end of his journey, Scrooge is no longer the miserly, grumpy individual he once was but a man who has experienced a change of heart and generosity, particularly during Christmas Day. This transformation is a testament to the powerful lessons he learns from the spirits and his reflections on his past, present, and future.

Marley is Scrooge's deceased former business partner, who has been dead for seven years. His face appears on the knocker of Scrooge's door, and he seems to haunt Scrooge. Marley is remembered by Scrooge and is described as being "as dead as a door-nail." As a ghost, Marley appears to Scrooge dragging chains made of cash-boxes, keys, padlocks, ledgers, deeds, and heavy purses wrought in steel.
Tim is a character mentioned in the context of being someone's blood-horse
St. Paul's Churchyard is a location mentioned as a breezy spot
Uncle Scrooge is another reference to Scrooge, who came to dinner
Marley's Funeral is an event that confirmed Marley's death

Scrooge's nephew is a cheerful, good-humored, and warm-hearted individual who consistently tries to spread Christmas cheer despite Scrooge's negative attitude. He expresses sympathy for Scrooge and makes efforts to include him in Christmas celebrations. Additionally, he is known for laughing heartily and hosting games, and he notably led a toast to Scrooge.
The counting-house is the office where Scrooge works, characterized by its cold and bleak environment. It is also the place where Scrooge and Jacob Marley conducted their business.

Christmas Eve is a significant day mentioned in various contexts. It is the time when Jacob Marley died seven years ago. Additionally, it is the day before Christmas, celebrated by Bob Cratchit and noted in the context of Scrooge's disdain. On Christmas Eve, Scrooge is busy in his counting-house, highlighting his preoccupation with work over festivities. Furthermore, Christmas Eve is the occasion during which Old Fezziwig hosts a lively and generous celebration, including dancing, food, and merriment.

The City is a bustling and busy place, especially during Christmas-time activities, where Scrooge and the Ghost observe the lively atmosphere. It is the heart of the city where Scrooge and the Phantom find themselves, and it is also where Scrooge's business friends are located, who would be surprised to see his emotional state. This city is not only where Scrooge and the Spirit find themselves but also where Scrooge lives and eventually becomes known as a good man. Additionally, the city is home to Scrooge's counting-house, which is characterized by cold, bleak, and foggy weather.
Offices near Scrooge's counting-house, where candles are flaring in the windows due to the dark and foggy weather.

The court, located outside Scrooge's counting-house, is a bustling area where labourers are diligently working. Despite the cold weather, people gather around a fire in an attempt to warm themselves. This scene highlights the harsh conditions and the communal efforts to find some comfort amidst the chill.
The CLERK works for Scrooge and is sympathetic to the nephew's views on Christmas.

NEPHEW
Fred, who is Scrooge's nephew, is a character who warmly welcomes Scrooge to dinner. He consistently tries to convince Scrooge of the goodness of Christmas and extends an invitation for him to dine, embodying the spirit of generosity and familial love.
Scrooge and Marley is the counting-house or business where Scrooge works. It represents the business partnership between Scrooge and Marley.
Two gentlemen who visit Scrooge's office to seek donations for charity

CHRISTMAS is a festive season during which people celebrate and make provisions for the poor and destitute. It is a recurring event in the text, associated with Scrooge's memories and emotions, and is central to the story and the characters' interactions. The holiday is celebrated by various groups of people, including the Cratchit family during their dinner. It is marked by kindness, festivities, family gatherings, and festive activities and decorations. Christmas is also the holiday during which many of the events and reflections of Scrooge take place, symbolizing joy and reflection. Additionally, it is during Christmas that the Ghost of Christmas Present makes an appearance. While Scrooge is initially cynical about Christmas, his nephew finds it valuable and good.
Union workhouses are institutions where the poor and destitute are provided with basic necessities in exchange for labor
The Treadmill is a form of punishment and labor used in workhouses
The Poor Law is legislation aimed at providing relief for the poor, often through workhouses
The Lord Mayor is a high-ranking official who oversees the city and has a household that celebrates Christmas in a grand manner
Mansion House is the official residence of the Lord Mayor
St. Dunstan is a historical figure known for his legendary battle with the Evil Spirit
The Evil Spirit is a mythical figure who is said to have been defeated by St. Dunstan

"CHRISTMAS CAROL" refers to a song traditionally sung during the Christmas season to spread cheer and goodwill. Additionally, it is depicted as a song sung by a boy at Scrooge's door the previous night, highlighting its role in festive storytelling and cultural traditions.
The poor and destitute individuals who suffer greatly and are in need of common necessities and comforts
Labourers who are repairing gas-pipes and warming themselves by a fire in the street
A group of impoverished individuals gathered around a fire to keep warm
A tailor who was fined by the Lord Mayor and is preparing for Christmas with his family
The wife of the little tailor, who is described as lean and is preparing for Christmas
The baby of the little tailor and his lean wife, who is part of the family preparing for Christmas

The CHURCH is an ancient structure featuring a tower with a gruff old bell that strikes the hours and quarters. It serves as a gathering place where people come dressed in their best clothes and with their gayest faces. Notably, it is also the place where Bob Cratchit and Tiny Tim went before returning home.
The main street where labourers are repairing gas-pipes and people are warming themselves by a fire
The gas-pipes being repaired by labourers in the main street
A water-plug left in solitude, whose overflowings have turned to ice
Shops with bright windows displaying holly sprigs and berries, making faces ruddy as people pass by
Shops that are part of a splendid joke and a glorious pageant during the Christmas season
The City of London is the location where Scrooge resides and works
Camden Town is the location to which Scrooge plans to send the turkey. Additionally, Camden Town is where Bob Cratchit runs home to play blind man's-buff.
Marley's face appearing on the knocker is a supernatural event that startles Scrooge
The Dutch merchant is the person who built the old fireplace in Scrooge's house
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
The wine-merchant owns the cellar below Scrooge's house
A legislative act mentioned in a metaphor about the width of Scrooge's staircase
A vehicle for carrying a coffin, which Scrooge imagines going up his staircase
Street lamps mentioned in the context of the darkness in Scrooge's house
Religious texts depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
A biblical reference used to describe Marley's face overshadowing other thoughts
Supernatural beings described as dragging chains in haunted houses
Houses believed to be inhabited by ghosts, mentioned in the context of Scrooge's experience

GHOST is a supernatural entity that appears to Scrooge, described as a strange figure resembling both a child and an old man. This spirit accompanies Scrooge and guides him through various scenes, spreading mirth and joy while also prompting reflections and realizations. The Ghost shows Scrooge visions of his past, present, and future, including memories and potential outcomes, such as Tiny Tim's future. Additionally, the Ghost rebukes Scrooge for his past behavior, encouraging him to change his ways. The supernatural occurrence of Marley's ghost appearing to Scrooge is also part of this spectral guidance, emphasizing the importance of transformation and redemption.

Jacob Marley is the ghost of Ebenezer Scrooge's former business partner. In life, Marley was a business partner of Scrooge, but now he suffers in the afterlife for his earthly misdeeds. As a ghost, Marley appears to Scrooge to warn him about his fate and the impending visits of three spirits. His memory haunts Scrooge, reminding him of his past and serving as a supernatural messenger to guide him towards redemption.

PHANTOM, also known as the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, is a ghostly figure that plays a significant role in guiding Ebenezer Scrooge through a transformative and fearful experience. The Phantom accompanies Scrooge, pointing towards the head of a dead man and leading him through various scenes that reveal the grim future that awaits if he does not change his ways. This spirit is a crucial part of Scrooge's journey, providing a haunting glimpse into what lies ahead. The term "Phantom" is another name used to describe this ghostly visitor who helps Scrooge understand the consequences of his actions.
The world is referenced as the place where spirits wander after death if they did not do so in life
The Ward is mentioned as a figure who would have been justified in indicting the Ghost for making noise
Jacob is Scrooge's old partner whose death is mentioned. He appears as a ghost to Scrooge to warn him about his fate and the impending visits of three spirits.
The Three Spirits are supernatural entities that will visit Scrooge to offer him a chance to change his fate
Phantoms are spirits seen by Scrooge, wandering in the air, wearing chains, and lamenting their inability to interfere in human matters
A church near Scrooge's residence whose chimes are heard by Scrooge
The event warned by Marley's Ghost, where Scrooge is to be visited by another ghost when the bell tolls one

The SPIRIT is a supernatural entity that appears to Scrooge, described as a strange figure resembling both a child and an old man. This ghostly figure shows Scrooge visions of the future and warns him about Ignorance and Want. The Spirit, also referred to as the Ghost or the Phantom guiding Scrooge, has the ability to sprinkle incense from his torch to restore good humor. Throughout his encounters with Scrooge, the Spirit teaches him valuable lessons and guides him on a transformative journey.
A financial document mentioned by Scrooge, indicating a payment to be made to him
An open country road with fields on either side where Scrooge and the Ghost of Christmas Past stand
The period in Scrooge's life that the Ghost of Christmas Past is showing him
Ali Baba is a character from Arabian Nights, whom Scrooge recalls fondly from his childhood imagination
Valentine is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, mentioned alongside his wild brother Orson
Orson is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, mentioned alongside his brother Valentine
Damascus is a city mentioned in Scrooge's recollection of a story involving a character put down in his drawers at its gate
The Sultan's Groom is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, turned upside down by the Genii
The Genii are supernatural beings from Scrooge's childhood imagination, responsible for turning the Sultan's Groom upside down
The Princess is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, mentioned in relation to the Sultan's Groom
The Parrot is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, associated with Robin Crusoe
Robin Crusoe is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, likely a reference to Robinson Crusoe
Friday is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, likely a reference to Robinson Crusoe's companion
The main road that Scrooge and the Ghost leave to approach the mansion
A well-remembered lane that Scrooge and the Ghost travel down to reach the mansion
Part of the mansion's grounds, where fowls cluck and strut
Part of the mansion's grounds, overrun with grass
Part of the mansion's grounds, overrun with grass
The dreary hall inside the mansion that Scrooge and the Ghost cross

ROOM is a long, bare, and melancholy space within the mansion where Scrooge witnesses scenes from his past, present, and future. It serves multiple significant roles: it is the setting where Scrooge sees his younger self, where the matron and her children are gathered, and where the dead man lies, with Scrooge and the Phantom present. This room encapsulates various pivotal moments in Scrooge's journey, reflecting the somber and reflective atmosphere of his experiences.
An empty storehouse with an idle swinging door in the mansion's yard
The dull yard behind the mansion
A despondent poplar tree in the mansion's yard
A lonely boy reading near a feeble fire, representing Scrooge's younger self
The schoolmaster is a figure from Scrooge's past who interacts with him and his sister

The WAREHOUSE is the place of business where Fezziwig, Ebenezer Scrooge, and Dick Wilkins work. It is notably the location where Scrooge was apprenticed and where Fezziwig worked. Additionally, the warehouse is significant for hosting the Christmas Eve celebration.
Ebenezer is a former apprentice of Fezziwig, now grown into a young man, who is very much attached to his fellow apprentice, Dick Wilkins
The three Miss Fezziwigs are the daughters of Old Fezziwig, known for their beaming and lovable nature
Country that negotiated a swap of money in exchange for hostages
Capital of Firuzabad where the Aurelians were being held
Aurelian who spent time in Tiruzia's Alhamia Prison
Aurelian journalist who was held hostage
Bratinas national and environmentalist who was held hostage
Dick is one of the apprentices who praises Fezziwig and is part of Scrooge's past memories
The fair young girl is a character who speaks to Scrooge about how his pursuit of wealth has displaced her in his affections
The domestic ball is an event hosted by Fezziwig where guests dance and celebrate, ending at eleven o'clock
The girl is a character who was once in a relationship with Scrooge and is now a comely matron. Additionally, she is the girl who answers the door at Fred's house and shows Scrooge upstairs.
The matron is the same girl from Scrooge's past, now grown and with children

The children are characters who excitedly greet their father and interact with the Christmas toys and presents. They are the offspring of the matron, creating a tumultuous and lively scene. Specifically, they are the children of Bob Cratchit and Mrs. Cratchit, including Peter and Tiny Tim. Additionally, they are the children of the mother, who are playing and whose voices she can hardly bear.
The winter fire is a comforting element in the scene with the matron and her children

MOTHER is a character who is anxiously waiting for someone and is revealed by the Phantom to Scrooge. She is depicted sitting with her husband and daughter by the fireside, creating a scene of familial warmth and anticipation.
The second spirit is a supernatural entity that visits Scrooge after the first spirit
PARLOUR is a room in the house where the children and their emotions are described. Additionally, it is the space behind the screen of rags in Old Joe's shop where the characters gather.
The office is the place where Scrooge is seen by Belle's husband
The bedroom is where Scrooge finds himself after his encounter with the Ghost
The fireside is where the master of the house sits with his daughter and wife
Mistletoe is a type of plant with crisp leaves that reflect light, used as decoration in the room where the Ghost of Christmas Present appears
Ivy is a type of plant with crisp leaves that reflect light, used as decoration in the room where the Ghost of Christmas Present appears
Plenty's Horn is a symbolic reference to abundance, represented by the glowing torch held by the Ghost of Christmas Present
Great Britain is the country where the events are taking place, characterized by a gloomy climate and town
The people in the city are shoveling snow and engaging in festive activities on Christmas morning.
The house-tops are where people are shoveling snow and engaging in jovial activities
The Grocer's is a shop nearly closed on Christmas morning, filled with various goods and festive items
The Poulterer's is a shop that is half open on Christmas morning, selling poultry and other goods
The Fruiterer's is a shop that is radiant with fruits and other goods on Christmas morning

Christmas Day is the holiday being celebrated, which is central to the events in the text. It is the day on which the events in the Cratchit household take place, filled with joy, surprises, and a festive meal. Additionally, it is the occasion during which people are seen carrying their dinners to the bakers' shops. Christmas Day is also significant as the day Scrooge wakes up to after his transformative experience with the spirits.
The chapel is another place where people flock to in their best clothes and with their gayest faces
The baker is a character who shuts up his shop after the bells cease, and the progress of the dinners' cooking is seen in the thawed blotch of wet above each baker's oven
Bob Cratchit's dwelling is a modest four-roomed house that the Spirit blesses with the sprinklings of his torch
Master Peter Cratchit is the son and heir of Bob Cratchit. He is described as wearing a monstrous shirt-collar and is eager to show off his attire. He helps with the meal by mashing the potatoes.

Tiny Tim is the youngest son of Bob Cratchit and Mrs. Cratchit. He is a frail and ill child who uses a little crutch and has his limbs supported by an iron frame due to his condition. Despite his physical challenges, Tiny Tim is remembered fondly by his family for his thoughtful and hopeful nature, wishing to inspire others. His future is initially uncertain, but after Scrooge's transformation, Tiny Tim is shown to be alive and well, bringing joy and relief to the Cratchit family.
The place where Tiny Tim was taken by his siblings to hear the pudding singing in the copper.
Master Peter is a member of the Cratchit family who mashed the potatoes with incredible vigor
Miss Belinda is a member of the Cratchit family who sweetened the apple sauce and changed the plates
Martha is a member of the Cratchit family who dusted the hot plates
The dinner is the meal prepared and enjoyed by the Cratchit family, featuring a goose and pudding
A title given to Scrooge by Bob Cratchit, albeit sarcastically
Miners are people who live on a bleak and desert moor and are seen celebrating Christmas in a hut
A solitary lighthouse built on a dismal reef of sunken rocks, where two men are celebrating Christmas
A ship far away from any shore, where the crew is celebrating Christmas
A hut on the bleak and desert moor where miners and their families are celebrating Christmas
The sea that Scrooge and the Ghost travel over, encountering a lighthouse and a ship
An old man in the hut who sings a Christmas song to his family
A lamplighter who laughs as the Spirit passes by
Two men who watch the light in the lighthouse and celebrate Christmas
The crew of the ship who celebrate Christmas

Scrooge's niece is a musical character who plays the harp and participates in the games. She is described as exceedingly pretty, earnest, and opinionated, particularly about Scrooge's wealth and behavior.

Topper is a character who is a guest at Fred's dinner party. As a bachelor, he has his eye on one of Scrooge's niece's sisters. Topper is known for his keen observations, such as being able to tell you about the sharp girls at the gathering. He is also part of the musical family and actively participates in the games, particularly enjoying blind man's-buff.
Scrooge's niece's sister is the plump one with the lace tucker who blushes when Topper expresses his opinion
PLUMP SISTER is a character who participates in the games and is often pursued by Topper during blind man's-buff. Additionally, she is another guest at Fred's dinner party.
London is the city where the story takes place and where the animal in the guessing game lives
A children's party that Scrooge and the Spirit visited during their travels
The Christmas holidays are the time period during which Scrooge and the Spirit travel together
An almshouse is one of the places visited by the Spirit and Scrooge, where they observed cheerfulness despite poverty
A hospital is one of the places visited by the Spirit and Scrooge, where they observed cheerfulness despite illness
A gaol (jail) is one of the places visited by the Spirit and Scrooge, where they observed cheerfulness despite imprisonment
A boy representing ignorance, shown to Scrooge by the Spirit
A girl representing want, shown to Scrooge by the Spirit
The ghost of Scrooge's former business partner who predicted the arrival of the spirits
CHANGE is a location within the City where merchants gather.
Business men are wealthy and important individuals in the City who discuss the death of an unknown person
A red-faced gentleman with a pendulous excrescence on his nose who discusses the death of an unknown person
A great fat man with a monstrous chin who discusses the death of an unknown person
Old Scratch is a colloquial term used to refer to the Devil, mentioned by the business men
Old Joe is a grey-haired rascal who owns a shop dealing in second-hand goods
The laundress is a woman who enters Old Joe's shop with a heavy bundle
The undertaker's man is a man in faded black who enters Old Joe's shop

The town is depicted as an obscure part with a bad reputation, which Scrooge and the Phantom visit. It is also the place where Scrooge asks the Spirit to show him someone who feels emotion caused by a man's death.
A low-browed, beetling shop owned by Old Joe where second-hand goods are bought and sold
An infamous part of the town known for its bad reputation, where Old Joe's shop is located
The deceased man whose belongings are being plundered and discussed by Joe and the others
The event of a man's death, which is causing various emotions and reactions among the characters
Caroline's husband is a young man with a careworn and depressed face, who brings the news of the creditor's death
CREDITOR is a merciless individual whose death brings relief to Caroline and her family, including her husband.
The dark, empty house where the dead man lies
The bed on which the dead man lies
The location beneath which rats are gnawing in the room of death
The door that the cat is tearing at in the room of death
The window from which the mother looks out anxiously
The clock that the mother glances at while waiting
Peter is a character who interacts with Bob and is mentioned in relation to getting a better situation. Additionally, Peter is one of the Cratchit children.
Mr. Scrooge's nephew is a kind gentleman who offers help to Bob Cratchit
The house where Bob Cratchit and his family live
The place around which the Cratchit family gathers
The book that Peter is reading
The entrance to Bob Cratchit's house
The chair set close beside Tiny Tim's body
The place where Bob Cratchit's tea is kept warm
The street where Mr. Scrooge's nephew meets Bob Cratchit
The day Bob Cratchit promises to visit Tiny Tim's grave
Bob is a character who speaks about his good wife and Tiny Tim
A place where Scrooge sees the grave with his name on it
The place where Scrooge works and sees a different figure in the chair
The gate that Scrooge and the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come pass through before entering the churchyard
The Ghost of Christmas Future, also known as the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, shows Scrooge the potential future consequences of his actions
The Past is one of the time periods that Scrooge vows to honor and learn from after his transformative experience
The Present is one of the time periods that Scrooge vows to honor and learn from after his transformative experience
The Future is one of the time periods that Scrooge vows to honor and learn from after his transformative experience
The portly gentleman is a character who had previously visited Scrooge's counting-house to ask for donations
The lad is the boy who Scrooge asks to buy the turkey and bring it to him
Joe Miller is mentioned in comparison to the joke of sending the turkey to Bob Cratchit
Fred's wife, who is surprised by Scrooge's arrival at the dinner party
Fred's wife, who is in the dining room when Scrooge arrives
Illustration is a visual representation included in the text to depict scenes from the story

The Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation (PGLAF) is a non-profit 501(c)(3) educational corporation organized under the laws of Mississippi. Established in 2001, its primary mission is to ensure a secure and permanent future for Project Gutenberg and its objectives. PGLAF owns a compilation copyright in the collection of Project Gutenberg™ electronic works and is dedicated to promoting free access to these electronic works. Additionally, the foundation manages the Project Gutenberg trademark and oversees royalty payments and permissions related to the use of Project Gutenberg's materials.

The trademark associated with Project Gutenberg works
The United States, where Project Gutenberg conducts copyright research and transcribes works not protected by copyright law
The FOUNDATION refers to the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation, which manages the Project Gutenberg trademark and handles royalty payments and permissions.

Professor Michael S. Hart was the originator of the Project Gutenberg concept, creating a library of electronic works that could be freely shared with anyone. He produced and distributed Project Gutenberg eBooks for forty years with the support of volunteers.
Salt Lake City is the location of the business office of the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation.
Mississippi is the state under whose laws the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation is organized.
The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is the U.S. government agency that granted tax-exempt status to the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation.
Utah is the state where the business office of the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation is located, specifically in Salt Lake City.

Professor Michael S. Hart was the originator of the Project Gutenberg concept, creating a library of electronic works that could be freely shared with anyone. He produced and distributed Project Gutenberg eBooks for forty years with the support of volunteers.

edge.data: Project Gutenberg is an organization based in the United States that distributes electronic works. Most of the works in Project Gutenberg are in the public domain in the United States. The organization operates within the United States and complies with its laws.
Project Gutenberg distributes 'A Christmas Carol' as part of its collection

The Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation manages the Project Gutenberg trademark and handles royalty payments and permissions. Professor Michael S. Hart was the originator of the Project Gutenberg concept and produced its eBooks for forty years.
Charles Dickens is the author of "A Christmas Carol"
Arthur Rackham is the illustrator of "A Christmas Carol"
J. B. Lippincott Company is the original publisher of "A Christmas Carol"
The Foundation complies with charity laws in all 50 states of the United States.
Suzanne Shell is one of the producers of the Project Gutenberg eBook of "A Christmas Carol"
Janet Blenkinship is one of the producers of the Project Gutenberg eBook of "A Christmas Carol"
The Online Distributed Proofreading Team helped produce the Project Gutenberg eBook of "A Christmas Carol"
Philadelphia is one of the cities where "A Christmas Carol" was originally published
New York is one of the cities where "A Christmas Carol" was originally published
Marley's Ghost is the first chapter of "A Christmas Carol"

edge.target: THE FIRST OF THE THREE SPIRITS
edge.data: The First of the Three Spirits is the second chapter of "A Christmas Carol"

edge.target: THE SECOND OF THE THREE SPIRITS
edge.data: The Second of the Three Spirits is the third chapter of "A Christmas Carol"
The Last of the Spirits is the fourth chapter of "A Christmas Carol"
The End of It is the fifth and final chapter of "A Christmas Carol"
Bob Cratchit is the clerk to Ebenezer Scrooge in "A Christmas Carol"

Bob Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol" who has a son named Peter Cratchit. Peter Cratchit is the son of Bob Cratchit, and both characters are featured in the classic story "A Christmas Carol."
Tim Cratchit, also known as Tiny Tim, is the youngest son of Bob Cratchit in "A Christmas Carol"

Bob Cratchit and Mrs. Cratchit are husband and wife, working together to support their family. They are married and part of the Cratchit family. Mrs. Cratchit is Bob Cratchit's wife, and they are characters in "A Christmas Carol."
Belinda Cratchit is a daughter of Bob Cratchit in "A Christmas Carol"

Bob Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol" who has a daughter named Martha Cratchit. Martha Cratchit is one of Bob Cratchit's children, and she plays a role in the story as part of the Cratchit family.

Bob Cratchit is Scrooge's clerk and works for him. Scrooge, who is Bob Cratchit's employer, initially shows reluctance to give Bob a day off on Christmas Eve. However, Scrooge undergoes a change of heart and decides to raise Bob Cratchit's salary and assist his struggling family. In addition to this, Scrooge plans to send a large turkey to Bob Cratchit as a surprise gift. Scrooge also takes an interest in observing Bob Cratchit's family, indicating his growing concern and compassion for their well-being.
Bob Cratchit runs home to Camden Town to play blind man's-buff
Bob Cratchit celebrates Christmas Eve by sliding on Cornhill and running home
Bob Cratchit slides on Cornhill in celebration of Christmas Eve
The Spirit blesses Bob Cratchit's house with the sprinklings of his torch
The Ghost of Christmas Present blesses Bob Cratchit's house, demonstrating a supernatural connection to the Cratchit family.
Bob Cratchit lives in a modest four-roomed house

Bob Cratchit is the father of Tiny Tim and shows great affection and concern for him. He is very caring towards Tiny Tim, often carrying him on his shoulder and being deeply concerned about his health. Tiny Tim, in turn, is Bob Cratchit's son.
Bob Cratchit celebrates Christmas Day with his family. Christmas Day is significant for Bob Cratchit as it is the day he spends with his family, filled with joy and celebration.
Bob Cratchit lives in the Cratchit dwelling with his family.
Bob Cratchit took Tiny Tim to the church before returning home.
Bob Cratchit is a member of the Cratchit family
Bob Cratchit is celebrating Christmas with his family. The events are taking place during Christmas.
Bob Cratchit is participating in the family dinner
Bob Cratchit is the father of Peter
Mr. Scrooge's nephew offers help to Bob Cratchit
Bob Cratchit lives in this house with his family
Bob Cratchit is the father of the children
The Cratchit family gathers around the fire
Bob Cratchit sits in the chair beside Tiny Tim's body
Bob Cratchit's tea is kept warm on the hob
Bob Cratchit meets Mr. Scrooge's nephew in the street
Bob Cratchit promises to visit Tiny Tim's grave on Sunday
Fred is the nephew of Ebenezer Scrooge in "A Christmas Carol"
The Ghost of Jacob Marley is the spectre of Scrooge's former partner in business in "A Christmas Carol"
Fan is the sister of Scrooge in "A Christmas Carol"

Jacob Marley, as a ghost, visits Ebenezer Scrooge to warn him about the consequences of his actions and to inform him about the impending visits of three spirits. This encounter serves as a crucial turning point for Scrooge, highlighting the dire fate that awaits him if he does not change his ways.
The Ghost appears to Ebenezer Scrooge and is described in detail. The Ghost visits Scrooge to warn him about the consequences of his actions.
The Phantom, another term for the Ghost, interacts with Ebenezer Scrooge
The counting-house is where Scrooge and Jacob Marley conducted their business

Ebenezer Scrooge is haunted by Marley's Ghost, the apparition of Jacob Marley. Marley's Ghost appears to Scrooge to warn him about his impending fate and to inform him of the future visitations by three spirits. This haunting serves as a crucial turning point for Scrooge, setting the stage for the transformative experiences that follow.
The Three Spirits will visit Scrooge to offer him a chance to change his fate

edge.target: THE FIRST OF THE THREE SPIRITS
edge.data: The First of the Three Spirits will visit Scrooge
Scrooge is warned by Marley's Ghost about a visitation
Scrooge hears the chimes of the neighbouring church
Scrooge hears the chimes of the neighbouring church
The Spirit appears to Scrooge and is described in detail
Scrooge mentions the First of Exchange as a financial document
Scrooge reads his own name, Ebenezer Scrooge, on a neglected grave
Peter Cratchit celebrates Christmas Day with his family
Mr. Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig are partners in dancing and hosts of the domestic ball. Mrs. Fezziwig is the worthy partner of Mr. Fezziwig in "A Christmas Carol."
Mr. Fezziwig hosts the domestic ball, spreading cheer among the guests

Fred, who is Scrooge's nephew, invited his uncle Scrooge to dinner. Despite Scrooge's unpleasant nature, Fred expresses sympathy for him and warmly welcomes him. Fred also hosted a game where Scrooge was the subject, demonstrating his inclusive and forgiving attitude towards his uncle.
Uncle Scrooge is invited to dinner by Fred
Fred enjoys Christmas and finds it a time for laughter and good-humor
Topper is a guest at Fred's dinner party
The plump sister is a guest at Fred's dinner party
The Ghost of Christmas Past visits Scrooge to guide him through his memories, showing him scenes from his past for his reclamation.
The Ghost of Christmas Past is associated with the period of Christmas Past

Scrooge is guided by the Ghost of Christmas Present, who appears to him to show the spirit of the holiday. The Ghost of Christmas Present shows Scrooge scenes from the present, including the current state of his life and the lives of others. During their journey, Scrooge recalls seeing people and is introduced to Ignorance and Want, gaining insight into the current state of affairs.
The Ghost of Christmas Present embodies the spirit of the Christmas holiday
Holly is part of the festive decorations surrounding the Ghost of Christmas Present
Mistletoe is part of the festive decorations surrounding the Ghost of Christmas Present
Ivy is part of the festive decorations surrounding the Ghost of Christmas Present
The Ghost of Christmas Present holds a glowing torch shaped like Plenty's Horn
The Ghost of Christmas Present, also referred to as the Spirit, is a specific form of the Spirit.
The Ghost of Christmas Present is associated with Christmas Day, spreading joy and blessings.

edge.source: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS YET TO COME
edge.data: The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come shows Scrooge visions of the future, highlighting the potential future consequences of his actions.
The Ghost of Jacob Marley warns Scrooge about the visits from the three spirits
Joe discussed bed-curtains with a woman, which is related to Scrooge's story
Joe appraises and buys items brought by Mrs. Dilber
Joe appraises and buys items brought by the woman
Joe appraises and buys items that were taken from the unhappy man
Fezziwig is the former employer of Dick Wilkins, and they share a warm relationship, especially evident during the Christmas Eve celebration
Ebenezer and Dick Wilkins were fellow apprentices and shared a close bond
Dick Wilkins works at the warehouse and participates in the Christmas Eve celebration
Belle is an old friend of Scrooge, and her husband mentions seeing Scrooge
Belle is the wife of the father
Belle sits with her husband and mother by the fireside
Caroline and her husband discuss the death of the creditor and its implications
Caroline feels relief upon hearing about the death of the merciless creditor.
Caroline and her husband live in the town where the creditor's death has an impact
Mrs. Cratchit and Belinda Cratchit are mother and daughter, working together to prepare the family meal.
Mrs. Cratchit and Master Peter Cratchit are mother and son, with Peter helping in the kitchen by mashing the potatoes.
Mrs. Cratchit and Martha Cratchit are mother and daughter, with Mrs. Cratchit warmly welcoming Martha when she arrives home.
Mrs. Cratchit lives in the Cratchit dwelling with her family.
Master Peter is a member of the Cratchit family and helps with the dinner preparations
Miss Belinda is a member of the Cratchit family and helps with the dinner preparations
Martha is a member of the Cratchit family and helps with the dinner preparations
Mrs. Cratchit is the mother of Tiny Tim. Tiny Tim is a member of the Cratchit family and part of the dinner scene.
Mrs. Cratchit is a member of the Cratchit family
Mrs. Cratchit is celebrating Christmas with her family
Mrs. Cratchit is participating in the family dinner
Mrs. Cratchit celebrates Christmas Day with her family
Mrs. Cratchit is the mother of Peter. She speaks to Peter about his future.
Mrs. Cratchit is the mother of the children
Bob and Mrs. Cratchit are married and interact with each otherMrs. Cratchit is Bob's wife and interacts with him
Belinda Cratchit lives in the Cratchit dwelling with her family.
Martha Cratchit and Tiny Tim are siblings, with Martha hiding to surprise her father and being part of the family celebration.
Martha Cratchit lives in the Cratchit dwelling with her family.
Martha Cratchit celebrates Christmas Day with her family
Mrs. Dilber interacts with Old Joe in his shop
Mrs. Dilber and the laundress meet in Old Joe's shop
Mrs. Dilber and the undertaker's man meet in Old Joe's shop
The charwoman and Mrs. Dilber meet in Old Joe's shop
Fan is Scrooge's sister who comes to bring him home for Christmas
Fan brings Scrooge home for Christmas

Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig are a married couple who actively participate in the Christmas Eve festivities. They are known for being partners in dancing and for hosting the domestic ball. Old Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig are often seen dancing together, adding to the joyous atmosphere of the celebrations.
Mrs. Fezziwig participates in the Christmas Eve celebration hosted by Fezziwig
Mrs. Fezziwig participates in the Christmas Eve celebration at the warehouse

edge.source: THE FIRST OF THE THREE SPIRITS
edge.data: The First of the Three Spirits will visit Scrooge

Marley's Ghost is the apparition of Jacob Marley, who appears to Scrooge to warn him about his impending fate and the forthcoming visits of three spirits. This event involves Scrooge, who is initially confronted by the ghost of Marley and reacts with disbelief.
Marley's Ghost informs Scrooge about the visits of the Three Spirits
Fezziwig was Scrooge's employer during his apprenticeship
Fezziwig runs the warehouse where the Christmas Eve celebration takes place. Additionally, Fezziwig worked at the warehouse where Scrooge was apprenticed.
Fezziwig is the former employer of Ebenezer, and they share a warm relationship, especially evident during the Christmas Eve celebration
Fezziwig is the father of the three Miss Fezziwigs, who are known for their beaming and lovable nature
Fezziwig hosts a lively and generous celebration on Christmas Eve
Scrooge speaks to the Ghost about Fezziwig, showing his fond memories of his former employer
Fezziwig hosts the domestic ball, spreading cheer among the guests

SCROOGE and MARLEY were business partners during their lifetimes. Marley, who has been dead for seven years, now appears to Scrooge as a ghost. Scrooge was Marley's sole executor, and he is haunted by the memory and face of Marley, whose visage even appears on the knocker. Their past connection is significant, as Marley continues to play a role in Scrooge's life from beyond the grave.
Tim is mentioned in the context of Scrooge's story
Old Scratch is mentioned in a conversation related to Scrooge
Scrooge attended Marley's Funeral and was his sole executor

Scrooge's nephew is a character who, despite Scrooge's unpleasant nature and negative attitude towards Christmas, consistently tries to engage with him and spread Christmas cheer. He is related to Scrooge and expresses sympathy for him. Scrooge's nephew makes efforts to include Scrooge in Christmas celebrations, even hosting a game and leading a toast to Scrooge. His actions demonstrate a persistent attempt to connect with Scrooge and share the joy of the holiday season.
Scrooge works in the counting-house, which reflects his cold and unfeeling nature

On Christmas Eve, Scrooge is busy working in his counting-house, demonstrating his disregard for the holiday. His lack of holiday spirit is further highlighted by his reluctance to give Bob Cratchit a day off on Christmas Eve.

SCROOGE is an employer who runs a counting-house where the CLERK works. The CLERK, who shares the nephew's positive views on Christmas, endures a cold environment while working for SCROOGE. Despite the challenging conditions, the CLERK maintains a positive outlook on the holiday season.

Scrooge and the Spirit find themselves in the heart of the city during Christmas, observing the bustling activities around them. The city, where Scrooge lives and works, is described as cold, bleak, and foggy. Despite this, Scrooge becomes known as a good man in the city. His business friends in the city would be surprised to see his emotional state.
The neighbouring offices are near Scrooge's counting-house, and their candles are visible through the fog
The court is outside Scrooge's counting-house, where people are trying to warm themselves

Scrooge is the uncle of his nephew, who is the child of his sister Fan. They have differing views on Christmas, which often leads to disagreements between them. Despite these differences, Scrooge is welcomed by his nephew Fred to the dinner party, indicating a sense of familial bond and hospitality.
Scrooge is the surviving partner of the business Scrooge and Marley. He works at Scrooge and Marley, the counting-house.
The portly gentlemen visit Scrooge to seek donations for charity

SCROOGE has a complex and evolving relationship with CHRISTMAS. Initially, Scrooge is notably cynical and uncharitable during the Christmas season, often expressing his disdain for it by calling it a humbug. His negative opinion is deeply rooted in his past experiences and reflections, many of which are centered around Christmas. Scrooge's emotions and memories associated with this holiday are intricate and multifaceted.
Throughout the narrative, Scrooge undergoes a significant transformation, largely influenced by supernatural events and interactions with various Ghosts that occur during Christmas. These experiences lead him to observe and reflect deeply on his life and actions. As a result, Scrooge gradually softens his stance on Christmas, learning valuable lessons that ultimately change his outlook.
By the end of his journey, Scrooge learns to keep Christmas well and becomes a generous and kind-hearted individual. His transformation is a testament to the profound impact that the Christmas holiday and its associated events have on him, marking a complete turnaround from his initial cynicism to a newfound appreciation and celebration of the season.
Scrooge supports the Union workhouses as a means to provide for the poor
Scrooge mentions the Treadmill as a form of punishment and labor for the poor
Scrooge references the Poor Law as a means to support the poor

"SCROOGE" is a character who has a notably negative reaction to a Christmas carol sung at his keyhole. Despite this reaction, he also recalls an instance where a boy sang a Christmas carol at his door. This duality highlights Scrooge's complex relationship with Christmas and its associated traditions.

Scrooge and the gentleman have a notable interaction where the gentleman approaches Scrooge to ask for donations for the poor. In a surprising turn of events, Scrooge, who is typically known for his miserly ways, surprises the gentleman with his generosity. This encounter highlights a significant moment of change in Scrooge's character, showcasing his newfound willingness to help those in need.
The church's bell strikes the hours and quarters, which Scrooge can hear
Scrooge lives and works in the City of London
Scrooge is startled by the appearance of Marley's face on the knocker
The Dutch merchant built the old fireplace in Scrooge's house
The wine-merchant owns the cellar below Scrooge's house, where strange noises are heard
Scrooge imagines a hearse going up his staircase
Scrooge hears noises that he associates with ghosts dragging chains
Scrooge's house is described with elements typical of haunted houses

Jacob Marley was Scrooge's business partner in life and now appears to him as a ghost. As a spectral figure, Jacob Marley plays a crucial role in the transformation of Scrooge by warning him about the impending visits from three spirits. Marley's ghostly presence not only predicts the arrival of these supernatural messengers but also actively sends them to Scrooge. Throughout this supernatural encounter, Jacob Marley's memory haunts Scrooge, serving as a constant reminder of his past and urging him to change his ways.

SCROOGE is a character who interacts with the GHOST, experiencing a range of emotions as he reflects on his past. Initially, SCROOGE is confronted by the ghost of Jacob Marley, which he disbelieves. Throughout their interactions, the GHOST accompanies SCROOGE, guiding him through various scenes, including those of Christmas celebrations and his past experiences. The GHOST shows SCROOGE visions of his life, influencing his reflections and prompting him to reconsider his life choices. Additionally, SCROOGE speaks with the GHOST about Tiny Tim's future, and the GHOST also shows him visions of the future, rebuking him for his actions. Through these experiences, SCROOGE is led to a deeper understanding of his life and the consequences of his behavior.
Jacob was Scrooge's old partner. He appears to Scrooge to warn him about his fate and the impending visits of three spirits.
The Three Spirits will visit Scrooge to offer him a chance to change his fate
Scrooge sees phantoms wandering in the air, lamenting their inability to interfere in human matters
Scrooge recognizes the market-town from his past
Scrooge and the Ghost of Christmas Past stand on the country road
The Ghost of Christmas Past shows Scrooge scenes from his past
Scrooge recalls Ali Baba fondly from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls Valentine from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls Orson from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls a story involving a character at the gate of Damascus
Scrooge recalls the Sultan's Groom from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls the Genii from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls the Parrot from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls Robin Crusoe from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls Friday from his childhood imagination
Scrooge visits the mansion with the Ghost
Scrooge and the Ghost leave the high-road to approach the mansion
Scrooge and the Ghost travel down a well-remembered lane to reach the mansion

Scrooge interacts with the Spirit to learn important lessons about his life and behavior. Throughout their encounters, Scrooge pleads for a chance to change his ways and asks the Spirit to show him someone who feels emotion caused by his death. He also questions the Spirit about his actions and intentions. The Spirit accompanies Scrooge, guiding him through various scenes, including Christmas celebrations and past memories, to reflect on his life choices. Additionally, the Spirit shows Scrooge visions of the future and warns him about the dangers of Ignorance and Want. Through these experiences, Scrooge gains a deeper understanding of the consequences of his actions and the importance of compassion and change.
The boy represents Scrooge's younger self
The schoolmaster interacts with Scrooge and his sister during their childhood
Scrooge was apprenticed at the warehouse where Fezziwig worked
Scrooge remembers his past with Dick, one of the apprentices
The fair young girl speaks to Scrooge about how his pursuit of wealth has displaced her

Scrooge encounters a girl and inquires if her master is at home, to which she responds by showing him upstairs. This girl was once in a relationship with Scrooge, but their relationship ended because of Scrooge's relentless pursuit of wealth.
Scrooge is seen by Belle's husband in his office
Scrooge finds himself in his bedroom after his encounter with the Ghost
The second spirit visits Scrooge after the first spirit
Scrooge and the Spirit stand in the city streets on Christmas morning

On Christmas Day, Scrooge is experiencing a profound transformation in his attitude and actions. After waking up from his transformative experience with the spirits, Scrooge begins to observe the events and interactions around him with a renewed perspective. His change in demeanor becomes evident as he becomes the subject of a toast, symbolizing the positive shift in how others perceive him. This day marks a significant turning point for Scrooge, highlighting his journey towards redemption and a more compassionate outlook on life.

Scrooge becomes a second father to Tiny Tim and ensures his well-being. He is deeply concerned about Tiny Tim's health and shows a genuine interest in his future, even going so far as to ask the Ghost about it. Scrooge's care for Tiny Tim is evident in his actions and thoughts, including a moment where he compares the size of a turkey to Tiny Tim. This relationship highlights Scrooge's transformation and his newfound compassion and responsibility towards Tiny Tim.
Scrooge is referred to as the Founder of the Feast by Bob Cratchit
Scrooge's niece is related to Scrooge and has strong opinions about his wealth and behavior
Scrooge lives in London, which is also where the animal in the guessing game lives
Scrooge and the Spirit visited a children's Twelfth-Night party
Scrooge and the Spirit traveled together during the Christmas holidays
Scrooge and the Spirit visited an almshouse where they observed cheerfulness despite poverty
Scrooge and the Spirit visited a hospital where they observed cheerfulness despite illness
Scrooge and the Spirit visited a gaol where they observed cheerfulness despite imprisonment
Old Jacob Marley predicted the arrival of the spirits to Scrooge

Scrooge, filled with terror, glances towards the Phantom, who is also known as the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come. The Phantom is guiding Scrooge through various scenes, showing him the future. Throughout this fearful experience, Scrooge is accompanied by the Phantom, who leads him through these ominous visions.
Scrooge and the Phantom are in Change, a part of the City
Scrooge observes the merchants in the City
Scrooge listens to the business men discussing the death of an unknown person
Scrooge listens to the red-faced gentleman discussing the death of an unknown person
Scrooge listens to the great fat man discussing the death of an unknown person
Old Scratch is mentioned in a conversation that Scrooge overhears
Scrooge visits an obscure part of the town
Scrooge visits an infamous part of the town
Scrooge is horrified by the treatment of the unhappy man's belongings
Scrooge is in the room with the dead man and the Phantom
Scrooge observes the bed where the dead man lies
Scrooge is in the dark, empty house where the dead man lies
Scrooge hears the sound of gnawing rats beneath the hearthstone
Scrooge notices the cat tearing at the door in the room of death
Scrooge and the Spirit cross the threshold of Bob Cratchit's house
Scrooge sees the grave with his name on it in the churchyard
Scrooge mentions the spirit of Tiny Tim
Scrooge sees his office with a different figure in the chair
Scrooge and the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come pass through the iron gate before entering the churchyard
The Ghost of Christmas Future shows Scrooge the potential future consequences of his actions
Scrooge vows to honor and learn from the Past
Scrooge vows to honor and learn from the Present
Scrooge vows to honor and learn from the Future
Scrooge plans to send the turkey to Camden Town
Scrooge meets the portly gentleman and offers a generous donation
Scrooge instructs the boy to buy the turkey from the poulterer
Scrooge asks the lad to buy the turkey and bring it to him
Scrooge compares the joke of sending the turkey to Bob Cratchit to a joke by Joe Miller
Scrooge surprises his niece by marriage with his arrival at the dinner party
Scrooge asks the girl about the mistress, who is in the dining room
Marley's face is described as overshadowing other thoughts like the ancient Prophet's rod

Scrooge's nephew and niece are a married couple who share opinions about Scrooge. Scrooge's niece, being an integral part of the family, actively participates in the games, bringing joy to Scrooge's nephew.
Jacob Marley's spirit never roved beyond the counting-house in life
Jacob Marley died seven years ago on Christmas Eve
The three Miss Fezziwigs participate in the Christmas Eve celebration hosted by Fezziwig
The Christmas Eve celebration takes place at the warehouse
The city is bustling with activities during Christmas
Change is a location within the city where merchants gather
Labourers are working at the corner of the court
The clerk shares the nephew's positive views on Christmas
The nephew values Christmas and believes it has done him good
Fred's wife is his niece by marriage

The Ghost is an entity associated with Christmas, known for spreading mirth and joy during the festive season. Additionally, the Ghost plays a significant role in showing Scrooge past Christmas events, helping to illuminate the spirit and meaning of Christmas through these reflective experiences.
The events and festive activities are taking place in Great Britain during Christmas
The Grocer's is nearly closed but filled with festive items on Christmas morning
The Poulterer's is half open and selling goods on Christmas morning
The Fruiterer's is radiant with fruits and other goods on Christmas morning
Master Peter is celebrating Christmas with his family
Miss Belinda is celebrating Christmas with her family
Martha is celebrating Christmas with her family
Tiny Tim is celebrating Christmas with his family
The Cratchit family is celebrating Christmas
The dinner is part of the Cratchit family's Christmas celebration
The miners are celebrating Christmas in their hut
Two men in the lighthouse are celebrating Christmas
The crew on the ship is celebrating Christmas
The Spirit is spreading mirth and joy during Christmas
The old man is singing a Christmas song to his family
The lamplighter laughs as the Spirit passes by, indicating the joy of Christmas
The two men in the lighthouse celebrate Christmas by making a fire and singing
The crew of the ship celebrate Christmas by humming tunes and sharing memories
Scrooge's niece also enjoys Christmas and expresses strong opinions about it
Topper is involved in the Christmas gathering and expresses his opinions during the event
Scrooge's niece's sister participates in the Christmas festivities
The Lord Mayor resides in the Mansion House and oversees the city's Christmas celebrations
The Lord Mayor fined the little tailor for being drunk and bloodthirsty in the streets
St. Dunstan is known for his legendary battle with the Evil Spirit
The gentleman is trying to raise funds to help the poor
Labourers are repairing gas-pipes in the main street
Ragged men and boys are gathered around a fire in the main street
The lean wife is the spouse of the little tailor
The baby is the child of the little tailor
The baby is the child of the lean wife
People flock to the church in their best clothes and with their gayest faces
Tiny Tim went to the church with his father, Bob Cratchit.
The water-plug is located in the main street and has turned to ice
Shops with bright windows are located in the main street
Poulterers' and grocers' trades are part of the shops in the main street
Jacob Marley is the Ghost who visits Ebenezer Scrooge. He appears as a ghost to Scrooge, serving as a harbinger of the supernatural events that follow.
The Ward would have been justified in indicting the Ghost for making noise
The Spirit and the Ghost are the same entity showing Scrooge scenes from his past
The Ghost shows Scrooge visions on Christmas Day
Jacob Marley is also referred to as the Phantom
Jacob Marley informs Scrooge about the visits of the Three Spirits
The Phantom and the Spirit are the same entity guiding Scrooge
The Phantom accompanies Scrooge to an obscure part of the town
The Phantom accompanies Scrooge to Old Joe's shop
The Phantom accompanies Scrooge to an infamous part of the town
Jacob informs Scrooge about the visits of the Three Spirits
The Spirit takes Scrooge to the city streets on Christmas morning
The Spirit restores good humor among people on Christmas Day
The Spirit blesses Bob Cratchit's dwelling with the sprinklings of his torch
Ignorance is a boy shown to Scrooge by the Spirit
Want is a girl shown to Scrooge by the Spirit
The Genii turned the Sultan's Groom upside down
The Sultan's Groom was married to the Princess
The stables are part of the mansion's grounds
The coach-houses are part of the mansion's grounds
The sheds are part of the mansion's grounds
The hall is inside the mansion
The room is inside the mansion
The matron is in the room with her children
The children are in the room with the matron
The winter fire is a comforting element in the room where the matron and her children are gathered
The storehouse is part of the mansion's grounds
The yard is part of the mansion's grounds
The poplar tree is in the yard
Ebenezer works at the warehouse and participates in the Christmas Eve celebration
The three Miss Fezziwigs participate in the Christmas Eve celebration at the warehouse
The matron is the same girl from Scrooge's past, now grown and with children
The matron is the mother of the children in the scene
The father is greeted by his children who excitedly interact with the Christmas toys and presents he brings
The children and their emotions are described in the parlour
The mother is anxiously waiting while her children play
Tiny Tim is one of the Cratchit children
Peter is one of the Cratchit children
The father sits with his wife by the fireside
The mother sits with her husband and daughter by the fireside
The mother looks out from the window anxiously
The mother glances at the clock while waiting

The undertaker's man enters the parlour
The people are shoveling snow and engaging in festive activities in the city streets
The people are shoveling snow and engaging in jovial activities on the house-tops
People flock to the chapel in their best clothes and with their gayest faces
Christmas Day is significant for Tiny Tim as it is a day of hope and inspiration for him, despite his condition. Tiny Tim celebrates Christmas Day with his family.
The baker interacts with the dinner-carriers who bring their dinners to the baker's shop
The grocer and his people serve the customers during the Christmas rush
Master Peter Cratchit and Tiny Tim are brothers, with Peter helping to fetch the goose and being part of the family celebration.
Master Peter Cratchit lives in the Cratchit dwelling with his family.
Tiny Tim lives in the Cratchit dwelling with his family.
Tiny Tim was taken to the wash-house by his siblings to hear the pudding singing in the copper.
Tiny Tim and Master Peter are siblings and part of the Cratchit family
Tiny Tim and Miss Belinda are siblings and part of the Cratchit family
Tiny Tim and Martha are siblings and part of the Cratchit family
Tiny Tim is a member of the Cratchit family
Tiny Tim is participating in the family dinner
Peter is the sibling of Tiny Tim
Tiny Tim's grave is visited by Bob Cratchit on Sunday
Bob speaks fondly of Tiny Tim and remembers him

The miners and their families are celebrating Christmas in the hut
The lighthouse is built on a dismal reef of sunken rocks in the sea
The ship is far away from any shore, in the middle of the sea
Topper has a romantic interest in Scrooge's niece's sister
Topper and the plump sister are both guests at Fred's dinner party. During the event, Topper often pursues the plump sister during the game of blind man's-buff.
Old Joe owns and operates the shop
